div.head: The Enemy in the Rear
div.excerpt: "A nation so lost to all sense of honor will not hesitate to turn smugglers at a time when success in belligerent demands may confirm the belief that we would not, or could not, resist such perfidious conduct."
div.summary: Reports that the British plan to violate the Morill tariff by smuggling iron goods into the western states of the U. S. and expresses disdain for the British because of this proposed action.

div.head: The New Congressional Apportionment
div.summary: Reports that Congress has altered the apportionment of Representatives from a number of states, including those that have seceded.

div.head: The Mails and the Flag
div.excerpt: "Most of the light and intelligence furnished to the Southern people has reached them through the mails from the North."
div.summary: Relates that the government is preparing to restore U. S. mail service to the occupied potions of the seceded states.

div.head: Disaffection of the Foreign Residents of Richmond
div.summary: Relates that the resistance that foreign residents of Richmond have exhibited toward the draft now in place has made other citizens of the city wary of foreigners in their midst.

div.head: A Reply to the Spirit
div.excerpt: "The following letter . . . is so much to the point, and is such a masterly reply to the attacks of certain kind [sic] of Democrats on the present Administration and the war to crush the Rebellion, that we adopt it as a most fitting reply to all the vomit heretofore ejected from the foul stomach of the Spirit, in its foul ravings against the Administration."
div.summary: Prints a letter from Forney's Washington correspondent that points out that certain "so-called Democratic leaders" use the same arguments pertaining to the war that are used by Jefferson Davis.

div.head: What the United States Note Law Contains
div.summary: Outlines the details of the new note law, which authorizes the issue of 150 million dollars in notes by the government.

div.head: The War in Arkansas
div.summary: Prints a dispatch that relates the poisoning of forty-two officers and men who ate food left by Southern troops when they retreated from Mud Town, Arkansas.

div.head: Gen. Banks in the Valley of Virginia
div.summary: Reports that Harper's Ferry, Charlestown, and Martinsburg are now occupied by United States forces. Refugees have returned to their homes, and those remaining "are overjoyed at our presence."

div.head: Nashville Occupied by U. S. Troops!
div.summary: Describes the scene in Nashville as the city was surrendered to Union forces.

div.head: Infernal Machines in the Savannah River
div.summary: Report of the discovery by the U. S. navy of torpedoes in the Savannah River.

div.head: Sent Off
div.summary: Reports that Lieut. Thomas, who is in town recruiting for the 77th Regiment of Pennsylvania, sent off ten recruits today, several of which are from Chambersburg.
Relates that the roof blew off of the Clay Lick School House previous Monday while school was in session. No one was injured, however.

div.head: Death of John Brown
div.summary: Expresses regrets at the death of former Chambersburg resident, John Brown. He died of lockjaw in Williamsport, where he had been compelled to seek asylum from his home in Virginia, where he had lived for the past several years.

div.head: Marriages
div.summary: Mr. S. Doyle Jones and Miss Emily Jones, daughter of Mr. John A. Jones, were married on February 23. All are residents of Metal township.
